{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3544127,"name":"Emre ","username":"DukeEmree","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dukeemree/{size}/251833_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-01T11:54:50.289Z","cooked":"

We are using ctre motion magic. We have some mechanical problems with our chain. So our elevator can‚Äôt accelerate fast. It should start slowly and go faster. I thought I should increase motion magic jerk. Also when elevator going down we have problem with gravity. It goes so fast. Any advice while tuning?
Position graph should be like this:

20250301_1453221920√ó2560 198 KB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-03-01T11:54:50.289Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":291,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":1505.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":493731,"topic_slug":"how-to-make-the-elevator-faster","display_username":"Emre ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64968,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-make-the-elevator-faster/493731/1","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3544144,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-01T12:49:24.992Z","cooked":"

Your position graph does not show the elevator starting slowly and going faster. The velocity (derivative of position) starts out highest at the start and gradually decreases over time.

If the elevator started slowly and then went faster, the position graph would be a sigmoid. Here is an example graph with position in blue and velocity in red. Ignore the blip in velocity as the elevator goes up. This happens to make sure our arm clears an elevator support.

To start more slowly (and finish more slowly), you should be decreasing acceleration and jerk.

If your elevator is going down too quickly, you likely do not have good feedforward control. An elevator feedforward model delivers motor voltage to compensate for the effect of gravity. Voltage is also varied to move the elevator up and down, but this voltage effectively adds to or subtracts from the voltage needed to suspend the elevator in position against gravity.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-03-01T12:49:24.992Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":220,"readers_count":219,"score":69.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":493731,"topic_slug":"how-to-make-the-elevator-faster","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/math/controller/ElevatorFeedforward.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ElevatorFeedforward (WPILib API 2025.3.1)","clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-make-the-elevator-faster/493731/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3544162,"name":"Battery Nerd - FRC #4561","username":"sdtrent","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/9de053/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-01T13:31:44.249Z","cooked":"

It looks like your PID tuning could be off? If P is too low, that leaves the heavy lifting to reach your final position to the Integral term which kind of sneaks up on the setpoint. Or you could have too much Derivative term, which can fight to limit your rate of change, but I think that is less likely.

You want your Proportional term to be high enough to get you you most of the way to the setpoint, but too much P can overshoot and cause oscillations.

Fast and Dirty PID Tuning

Start with P only (set I and D to zero)
Increase P until you get stable but noticeable oscillations around the setpoint, then back P off until the oscillations stop (10-40%). Your error goes up but the Integral term will correct it.

Add Integral Term (if needed)
If you notice a steady-state error (the motor never quite gets to setpoint), add some I (maybe 10% of P depending on your loop times) then slowly raise I to reduce the final error. If the system becomes too jumpy or overshoots (or oscillates), reduce I.

Add Derivate Term (if needed)
If you still see rapid oscillations or ‚Äúringing,‚Äù introduce a small amount of D to help dampen them. Maybe start with 10% of your Integral term. Be careful with D though, it is often not needed, and if needed, a little goes a long way. To much is likely to cause oscillations.

Shane
Battery Nerd
Mentor - FRC# 4561 - TerrorBytes

Are you sure you are looking like a position graph? That looks like either a velocity graph for a motor that is saturated, or the phase plane representation of a trapezoidal profile, both of which aren‚Äôt a position graph.

DukeEmree:

We have some mechanical problems with our chain. So our elevator can‚Äôt accelerate fast.

Fix these first. You cannot fix mechanical problems in software. Elevators inherently require high acceleration to move fast, and not being able to accelerate fast limits you to extremely slow movements.

Hi you are right. I post wrong graph. We tuned going down values with dynamic motion magic. But we have problems with going up. Now our elevator opens in 2 second when going full up. But when going closer points it is so slow. Its probably pid issue. We are thinking to use bigger pid with different slots. Our team wants more speed for elevator when going up. But when I speed up elevator‚Äôs position brokes. Our team says just start slowly wait elevator to cling chain then speed up. So velocity should go up slowly then speed up. We generated our pid values with sysID.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-03-01T22:15:30.256Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":64,"readers_count":63,"score":17.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":493731,"topic_slug":"how-to-make-the-elevator-faster","display_username":"Emre ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64968,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-make-the-elevator-faster/493731/8","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3544449,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-01T22:49:47.330Z","cooked":"

You don‚Äôt need or want a slew rate limiter with motion magic. The motion magic is a more sophisticated slew rate limiter. Instead of moving the elevator setpoint immediately from one goal level to another, motion magic creates a gradually moving setpoint that respects velocity, acceleration, and jerk constraints.

Turn down your acceleration and velocity in motion magic to see if you can slow the elevator movement, especially going down. If you can‚Äôt make the elevator move very slowly with small acceleration and velocity, you may have bad feedforward tuning.

If your feedforward is good, your PID feedback should have almost nothing to do. Try to get your motion close with just feedforward or maybe include just a tiny bit of P.
